awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Advanced Chemistries for Energy and Sensing Applications at the University of Tennessee
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates site award to the University of Tennessee Knoxville, located in Knoxville, TN, supports the training of 10 undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry, participants engage in research projects and receive mentoring to develop complementary professional skills critical for successful scientific careers. The individual research projects center around the theme of advanced chemistries for energy and sensing applications. The professional development and mentoring component places an emphasis on building undergraduates' communication skills through collaboration with the English Department.  The students create high quality science writing. This program also exposes participants to a variety of possible careers in chemical research through interaction with neighboring institutions such as the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

Undergraduates' research projects, falling under the broad umbrella of advanced chemistries for energy and sensing, include studying shape-changing polymeric materials, characterizing single-molecule magnets and chemical qubits, computationally studying polymeric membranes for gas separation, understanding structure-property relationships of polymerization catalysts, and designing liposomes for triggered release of encapsulated contents. This REU Site emphasizes the inclusion of a diverse group of undergraduates to address the under-representation of demographic groups.  Ultimately, this site works to develop a well-trained and diverse set of talented chemists primed for future contributions to academics, government service or industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to provide an intensive summer undergraduate research experience to prepare participating students for success in graduate school and/or future scientific careers by developing a range of relevant skill sets. A primary objective of the program was to recruit outstanding young scientists into scientific careers, and particularly focus on those students who have limited access to research opportunities at their home institutions. Through this funding, we provided training opportunities for a diverse group of 30 exceptional undergraduate students.

REU students engaged in wide-ranging research that, while focused on our central theme of novel materials for energy and sensing, nevertheless involved all five traditional chemistry divisions within our department (Analytical, Inorganic, Organic, Physical, and Polymer divisions). Students received specific laboratory training related to their desired research field along with departmental equipment including Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) and mass spectrometers. Participants experienced site visits to nearby Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) and Eastman Chemical to observe chemical research in both the government and industrial sectors (except in cases where there were travel restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic). In addition, students received general training in safety, professional ethics, weekly seminars by chemistry faculty, and science communication.

Beyond the research experience, the program also included training in comprehensive skills that are important for early scientists including ethics, modern research topics, and scientific communication. Communication skills were enhanced through a strategic collaboration with the English Department at the University of Tennessee. Through this partnership, faculty led several workshops for our REU students designed to enhance the specific skills of CV and resume writing, as well as the preparation and presentation of scientific posters and oral talks. Faculty partners provided workshops indicating best practices and assisted students by reviewing drafts of their documents. These faculty also attended practice talks given by REU students and provided tips for enhancing their presentations.  

A unique aspect of this program was the inclusion of an embedded science writer who prepared articles about each REU student for publication in their local and school newspapers. This was done to celebrate the accomplishments of our students and to publicize the program to unique audiences. A final symposium was held in which each student gave an oral presentation on the research they performed over the summer to faculty, graduate students and colleagues at Tennessee Chemistry. Overall, this program was carefully designed to advance the preparation of talented undergraduates for careers in scientific research.

At least 20 of the participants in this REU Program have thus far enrolled in graduate school related to the field of Chemistry. Other participants have begun jobs in either the private or government sectors. These REU students have additionally produced publications in peer-reviewed journals and given presentations on their work at prestigious conferences.
